content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Kinetic Void at first seemed to be a fairly promising title, I've been a space nut for a long time and am a huge fan of the older Homeworld series and the slightly more elusive 0-R-B Off-World Resource Base. So I got Kinetic Void when it was on sale for about $5, thinking why not, then the trouble started.The previews for the game show very good graphics with a beautiful star backdrop and detailed rendering of the ships, but with the latest update at over a year old, the skybox does not render meaning there are no stars, planets look like cheese, nebulae fog looks like sprites, etc etc, though the sun has a nice lens flare. Long story short, what you see in the previews is a little misleading.The game itself is still in development but had been on hold for a year now, it has virtually no backstory and not alot to do within the game. You can of course try to make the beefiest ship alive and go fight pirates, but that gets old quickly. Eventually you find yourself building giant flyswatters and pitting them against Imperial Star Destroyers if you dare to load up the game again.Possibly the only thing interesting about this game is it makes fan fiction possible, who would win, the Enterpise or a Starwars Republic Attack Cruiser, the Serenity or a Varkrey, an F-16 or a TIE fighter? Truthfully thats just about what this game has become due to lack of progress.Don't get me wrong, the game looks interesting, I'm hoping it gets better and finishes strong, but it's looking abandoned and in it's current state isn't worth the $20.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I bought this game during Early Access because the game looked hugley promising.  This seemed to be the game that would fill the void left in the absence of Elite, Escape Velocity, or a good X game after the abomination that is Rebirth.  Unfortunatley as development trucked along, much more slowly than originally promised at that, features in development began to be cut.  First the scale of the universe was reduced, then the Newtonian physics that were one of the huge selling points of the game were cut in favor of a "simplified" traditional flight model that has ships slow down when engines are cut, turn like atmospheric craft, and have velocity rather than acceleration limits (and these limits are VERY small, measured in triple-diget KPH in the enormity of a solar system).The robust mission and faction system never materialized, leaving players with very little more to do than in alpha stages.  Basically you can trade legitimatley, or pirate and sale.  The universe offers almost nothing else to do.  There are no indications of where one can buy and sell items let alone how the prices will fluctuate nor what ship modules will be available until you reach a system in the tiny galaxies generated each new time you start a game.  Even then what faction controls a star system (the number of which can be ajusted when you create a galaxy, but they are nothing more than interchangable names and their influence almost never changes for any reason).The one good thing that I can say about this game is that the ship editor is fairly large.  It was reduced in features since the alpha, again in an attempt to simplify which they failed at anyway, but still offers many options in terms of ship design.  The wide range of vessels both original and copies of famous ships from sci-fi series does attest to this.  Unfortunatley there is nothing to do with your ship other than mindlessly shoot other ships.If you think that Elite: Dangerous doesn't give you enough help in the universe nor enough interaction with the economy, NPCs, or factions, then stay away from this game.  The tutorials, to the VERY limited extent they exist at all, teach you nothing and somehow saying you recieve no guidence manages to be an understatement.  Even the graphics are nothing to write home about.  Actual old games like X3 or Escape Velocity Nova manage to be better at this, and if you want less story and more trade and exploration with a game that looks beautiful check out Elite: Dangerous or keep your eye out for the (as of time of writing) unreleased Star Citizen or No Man's Sky.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Not really a game. Cool shipbuilder. I was told there would be a game, though. I was incredibly shocked when I saw the other day that they are claiming it's out of EA. It's plainly not, they just stopped working on it. Exactly the kind of thing that gives EA games a bad name.Edit: It appears I was wrong to say that the devs had halted work on the game completely, thanks for the correction. As I looked into it it seems they have still been working on some monthly bug fixes and improvements. Though I don't think that any of the things I've seen listed in the change log really implore me to spend more time on the game even if many of the potential features that the devs have stated they'd like to add were to be added in the future, I'm happy to hear that the devs are still putting in some time.While I'm glad to hear that the devs are still working on it, the statement of calling it a 1.00 version as well as the specific avoidance of promises about what will or will not make it into the game still turn me off enough to wish I had put my money somewhere else, though I admit there's an outside chance I could reinstall on a whim in a year or two and be pleasantly surprised.So to sum up, the shipbuilding aspect is very well done and I'd say it's probably a lot less confusing than it might seem at first if you just take a few minutes to adjust yourself. It might still be a little obtuse at times, but you only have to check out the workshop to see how expansive it can be. However, the gameplay to my taste at least, still felt very underpolished and generally uninteresting to the point that I can't have a lot of hope it could ever be anything but outdated at best as of only one patch ago.If I've missed anything, please feel free to let me know so I can correct it.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												It has the potential to be a great spacesim. But it isn't, yet.It offers the perfect setting to play a Spacepirat, fight ships, blow them up, scavenge parts and wild them to your ship to gain strength. Sounds great, hasn't been there before. But sadly at the moment thats all there is to this game, the creative sandbox modus is nice for building ships but everythign around is lacking.Errors in the UI, for exampel the vendor menue the filters a weapons say EMP, Kinetic, Thermal... truth is, Beam, Projektile and Missile. Poor scaling of UI, you fight like Ace Combat... uh an red icon, klick, uh an red box around the icon and a red sircle and long bevor you can realy see the enemy it goes boom. You do have an targeing window that shows you a miniature of the enemy ship but i was unabel to detect any impact ov my weapon fire on the ship in the window seams that its yout an automatic generatet icon.Beeing a trader is almost imposibel, mining takes for ever and mission reward dosn't scale. Reward for a mission in a fighter gave me 5-10k reward mission in a corvette gave the same.The lift of things they have promised.Let's take small look ^^Fully detailed and customizable space ships.Yes best part of the game, surpasses to my eye customisation in Space Empire and Galactic Civ.Hundreds of weapons and modules of multiple sizes.There are many but to get to hundreads you have to use the Borderlands equation. Existing modules times classes, here 5. Very few klass exclusiv moduls.Fully customizable and adaptable controls for mouse, keyboard, and joystick.Yes its there.Huge procedurally generated galaxy, limited only by your computers capabilities.No it isn't the max sice is 30 systems and 12 factions.Randomized factions and political standings.For the most part. Open world sandbox, you are in control of your fate.Some one has to, the impulses from the world around do not exist. A chat mission every once in a while that tells you about a "mission" errand is no impulse.Detailed economy simulation with resources, trade routes and more.There are resources and you get chat messages that tell tales of lost shipment and impact on prices, but i never saw any ship docking at a station ore flying towards a gate for traderouts. The more part, thats the module trader at the station. BTW you can enter 50% of all stations... (there are only two kinds)Epic space combat.Epic means you get swarmd at a random mission by 5 exact copys of your own ship and get blastet out of the universe.Toggleable Newtonian FlightThats there and dose work for the most part. Max speed is caped at two times your normal max speed.Emergent gameplay.Well Space is big and i taked forever to get somewhere and mining an asteroid is pretty boring in real life as well if you sit in your command chair and watch the pretty light from the laser.So they realy more or less fullfilled the conditions on the list. To bad it'S not enough.This is a review you released the game to 1.0 and lost every protection of the EarlyAccses. The Programmers sad we are done its a finished product but it's not. number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Interesting in concept, lacking in content. This game has an atmosphere and flight experience that harkens back to the 90s and games like Star Quest I. This really isn't a good thing. On paper, the idea of a game where you can design, build and fly your space ships competely from the ground up the way you want them, is fantastic... but after spending a few hours messing around in the the game I couldn't even figure out what to do in the game, much less how to start building my own ship. The 'guide' was bare-bones at best and the interface was clunky and frustrating. As an early access game, some growing pains are expected, but this feels a lot less like a playable alpha and more like an unfinished engine with nothing to do in it. My recommendation is to skip this one for now and maybe check back later to see if things have improved before buying.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I picked this game up again recently, thinking it was still in Pre-alpha phase, but have just now read in another review that it is actually already released as a full game. To put it simply, I noticed no improvements that blew me away enough to even notice that this was the finished game, even after forgetting i owned this game and reinstalling it. I particularly don't like the way the ship-building interface is; it looks cheap and ugly. The game as a whole is difficult for me to play, as the controls seem nearly as ambiguous as what I should even be doing. I don't think I'm a terribly picky person, I understand a game does not need to rely heavily on complex themes or dazzling art styles and graphics to be playable, but this seems to be one of those games where it looks so sloppily put together, that it puts me off from wanting to even humor what gameplay is present. To tie a bow on it, I don't believe this game has any real potential anymore, so i don't recommend that anyone purchase it, and I regret buying it.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												THE ZOOM SPEED IN THE BUILD-A-SHIP SECTION IS UNBEARABLE!!!!!!!!!! It takes waaaaaay to long to zoom out/in to your ship in the construction menu, and the UI is horrific. Badly organised and ill explained jumble of icons that mean nothing to me. This could be so much better if these things were improved upon. The old UI in the early days of the game was VASTLY superior. It was better organised, more consise and easy to navigate. The older ship-builder was better too, now there is too much fiddling and clicking everywhere. The old one was click and place. not click and click again, and then learning you have placed it wrong so you have to remove it and then click then click again. It is such a shame, because this game is a great idea that feels as if it has been rushed. even the main gameplay is dull. Just don't bother throwing money at it, you'll find better uses of it elsewhere, preferably anything other than this heap of junk.

Early Access Review
								Preface: I've been asked by the game's developer to change my review, which follows as such.Tedious and unimersive come to mind when playing this game for any amount fo time, caused by a textwall tutorial system that definetly doesn't hand-hold the player at all, so you'll be devoting a hell of a lot of time reading away.It's not a game that you want to get into if you expected a fun, light Kerbal Space Program-like game, especially with the myriad of controls.If you were looking for a boring version of the X3 franchise, you've found it, with the added extra of: an unintuitive UII'm not going to directly attack the developer, however his attitude towards bad reviews leaves more to be desired. He should also note that threats to involve community moderators in order to coerce a good review do not work on me, and I still think this game is pretty abysmal.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I should preface this by asking you to ignore my hours in this game. I played quite a bit of it offline and apparently Steam doesn't track hours spent offline.I've said it before and I'll say it again: One of the most damning words you can use to describe a video game is "potential". With almost all of the absolute worst games of the last generation, "potential" was the best word people could use to describe them. Duke Nukem Forever, The Walking Dead: Survival Instinct, X-Rebirth, these all had massive potential and that is part of why they were considered such disappointments. If "potential" is the best word you have to describe a game, that game has failed, Early Access or no. And sadly, that is the best word I can use to describe Kinetic Void.I first picked up this game last year in May, actually getting it with a Steam card gifted to me for my birthday. I should've bought something else. This game barely had any content at the time, even for an Early Access game. Earlier this year Earth: Year 2066 was released in Early Access and was massively criticized for having next to no content and that's about what the game was like when I first bought it. You had access to plenty of ship customizations and...that was about it. Then you flew around in a very pretty screenshot area and then you stopped. That was about it. Rarely enemies would appear and then you would attack them in broken combat. Or maybe you went to a ship drydock (which it takes like 4 years to reach, more on that later) and found out that you couldn't dock. I get it, it's Early Access and things are gonna be buggy and broken, but when there's only 3 things to do in your game, you would expect those 3 things to actually work to some degree. So instead it turned into a pretty screenshot game and nothing more.Moving around in this game in absolutely awful. It takes FOREVER to reach anywhere. I get it, space is big but this is a video game, you are allowed to cut down on size if it makes the game more accessable and fun. Even in FTL mode it still feels like it takes ages to move around, up until you stop paying attention and crash into a planet. Scratch that, you never crash unless you're shot down, so all you do is clip through solid landmasses, whether it's a planet, a moon or a space station, you just clip through it.This could have been fixed by either cutting down on the size and scope to something more manageable or to include more things that happen along the way. Encountering Space Pirates (If the combat worked), seeing two fleets battling each other, encountering a stranded merchant ship, these all could have helped it not feel so empty and boring. As is, the exploration feels less like the magic and wonder of something like Skyrim and making me feel more like this: 


YouTube™ Video: ▶ Deadpool so boring  Make it stop 

			Views: 16,474		

			public use.deadpool is owned by marvel deadpool, deadpool the game Highmoon studios		

I haven't checked up too often on this game since then, I haven't really felt like revisiting this slog of a space explorer but after a years worth of updates I decided to revisit it. It isn't that much better now, sadly. After a year of updates it still feels the same to me, a bit like the difference between the DayZ mod and standalone: Months and months of work and nothing seems to have changed. Things are indeed different, but nothing big is different. Combat is still broken to the point of being unplayable and exploration still takes several millenia to ever do anything at all. Sorry kids, but until further notice, "potential" is the best word I can come up with for this game and "boring as hell" is the worst. Not recommended at all, only spend your money if you want to fund the development cycle. Otherwise, there's too many games for you to buy that desrve your money for you to waste any on this slog of a game.

The general idea is very interesting, but with tons of unfinished things, many bugs and so, i've waited for the early access stage to end.Now, with time to check again and because the game was officially released, in my opinion, the game's still a complete mess. The problems and bugs in the docks (where you put your ship parts together) remained there and i think that the UI is worse. I'm not sure, but trying to place the ship parts where you want, seems to be much more difficult than before.I wasn't able to check if the navigation/combat system was improved or at least fixed. The game keep crashing to desktop very often while in the dock. It didn't happen before, while the game was in early access.At least for now, i give up. I'm gonna wait for another major update patch and then I'll try again.Because of that, i can't recommend this game as it is.*****************************************************************************************************************UPDATEWell, this game is dead for sure now.The dev simply abandoned the game and gave us a great and loud "F*** YOU" while run off with our money. People say that the dev don't even reply any kind of contact anymore.Steam should be more responsible for letting this happen and give the money back to the clients. Afterall, they allowed this dev to sell their game while they had no capability or intention to keep working on the game.Obviously, this will not happen because Steam doesn't reeeally cares about clients too, but at least they should took this example (saddly, not the only one here on Steam) and formulate a more tight policy to verify which dev can or cannot be sold here.I know we are just clients, but a little bit of respect wouldn't hurt.

Posted: February 17, 2015
												The ship designer is cool.But it's the only thing about the game that could be called complete and efficient.Not only was the gameplay so poor that I couldn't even bring myself to play more than an hour outside the ship editor, whoever was behind this game forgot to finish the graphics engine.I don't even know how you miss that, forgetting to finish the graphics engine shows itself with spontaneous blooms of light filling the screen, weird looking planets (Their textures do not increase in detail with proximity, and they lack atmospheric effects for colour emissions) and very poor performance (Runs fine at full settings on my computer, but considering how dull the graphics are at max settings, that's no excuse for it to be generating a lot of heat or be unplayable with my old graphics card).

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												This game has kind of a sad history.  It looked REALLY good when it was on early access, and had a few people's support, but beyond the ship design most of it was clunky and hard to understand or manage.  I had a game once where I built a big ship and the only thing I could do was go into warp drive, because the other controls besides turning didn't seem to work.  I essentially hung dead in space.I got this game for the ship design.  While it has an unfinished feel to it, the ship building looks cool enough and a lot of it had a bunch of potential.  I myself will likely install it once or twice just to build some ships again so that I get a visual idea for something for a much better game, like say Space Engineers.  Beyond that, however, I probably will never play it again.  It was a waste of potential.  Kind of wished that the devs put more effort into it...or at the very least got some help in finishing the game.Sad day.  I hate making negative reviews.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								The main problem I have with the game is an utter lack of direction.  Specifically how to move.  It took me longer then it should have to figure out that the space bar is your acceleration.Next problem is the lack of a tutorial when it comes to ship making.  The way it is currently set up is simply "Heres your hanger, have fun".  What would help would be a tutorial option with ship making.Another tutorial that would help would be one dealing with space combat.  Enimies can snipe me from almost 30 Km away where as I can not see them at all.  That was after I figured out that Z actives your guns, but I still don't know what the other indicators on the center dial are.Okay, how to improve.  First a tutorail on some basic controls (movement, weapon selection, and the like), building your ship and space combat.  Until these are ironed out I can not recomend this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												This game was an achievement when it came to building your own really nice looking space ships, and all the different modules, details and work put into that system. Bought the game in early access because I really liked that concept and there was some cool♥♥♥♥♥looking ships in the workshop. Unfortunately development seemed to slow, and seemingly out of nowhere I saw it on Steam's main store page being that it was fully released version 1.0, After full release I tried playing the game, and could not for the life of me figure out how factions or missions worked at all. It seems that all the actual gameplay elements were rushed out and are not user friendly at all. It sucks, and I know that's the risk of early access. But I don't know how someone could take money from people in support of a product they're making and on the home stretch just throw it out there in such an unspectacular state. I understand that if you run out of money and the game's not selling due to its poor reviews, you've gotta get a day job. At least work towards making it a fun and accessible game in your free time from then on! Maybe in due time you'd get a chance to redeem yourself and your game and you'd start getting some sales, but whatever man. I guess♥♥♥♥♥♥happens. Could've been a great game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								Bear in mind this is still an incomplete game at this stage, so I will only review what feels like the most complete section, ship building.Honestly I was a little hesitant at first, I have had other games where you can make your own content fail to deliver misserably, and I am a huge fan of making my own things my own way.After getting to grips with placing the modules properly (which takes some time and mistakes) I completely forgot the time and before I knew it I had spent a whole evening making my first ship, which I was very proud of.With some time and dedication you can make some fantastic creations with this even at this stage of development, it only takes a quick look on the workshop to see people who have made some really special things already, even a gaint mech!This is already a fun game for those who enjoy the construction element in particular, the rest of the game is only really complete enough to take your creation for a joy ride and test out the fighting capabilities.That said if the completed game has the same level of effort put in to its construction this could be a masterpiece waiting to happen...Only buy at this point if you like games where you can make your own creations, and if you remember this is a game very much in development, do not expect a polished and complete experience yet!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												Very ambitious game with a *very* emphatic NOPE. The website still sells it as early access. Last update was over a year ago as of this writing. It states:  For a while now, our biggest problem has been a lack of content once you’ve built your ship, and an in-depth economy    will be a major factor in creating a living world for the player to interact with. This week’s patch includes an early implementation that should give you a basic idea of where we want to go with it. So basically with the final release, we have an "early implementation" of a "basic idea" for the economy. I'm certainly not trying to be antagonistic here, but that just seems blatantly wrong to me. It feels pretty deceitful to sell a product as complete when it has clearly not been finished. I really wanted to like it. It was one of the first early-access titles I've purchased and I admit, the ship builder is pretty fun. Flying your ship, or interacting with the universe on any meaningful level seems non-existant. Combat is boring and janky, the economy sim is incomplete, and the whole thing reeks of alpha. For clarification, alpha as in the pre-beta stage, beta meaning the game is feature complete and only requires bug fixing, optimization, and testing. In essence I'm saying that things are missing. Overall, once you finish building your ship, you may as well just quit the game; it's peaked. That was the high point, that was the single most fun thing that you will ever do in this game. It's just boring. Obviously, no developer sets their sights on making a boring game. I'm not mad, I understand money and motivation don't last forever, but this game really should have been *so* much more than what is offered. The procedural random galaxy and shipbuilder alone must have been truly momental tasks to overcome. I don't know what happened with the devs (the forums are malfunctioning or have been removed as of this writing), but it's genuinely as though they just vanished. If and when they do return, I hope that they will learn from their mistakes and move on.

								It was as if EVE Online and Kerbal Space Program had a baby, and that baby was a total badass. Build your ship to be whatever you desire and explore, fight, and be an interstellar accountant(I know that that may not sound fun, but it worked out great for EVE.) inside a beautiful universe which for some reason has awesome music playing in the backround. The reqirement specs are quite low, I know because I have a 720p 2009 iMac, and the framerate is pretty smooth at max settings. If you listen to the devs, then you can tell that they really care about Kinetic Void. This game has tons of potential, and I think that it's going to deliver. And if you don't like the game, then GLaDOS will give you cake!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Kinetic Void started off as a really good idea for a game. 100% open world, pure 'do-as-you-wish' ship construction and exploration.That's about all the good I can say about it.The dev team was really small, inexperienced, and although they were pretty active in the community and media, the game itself fell short by many expectations. There are still a lot of bugs, no actual tutorial, ship building in itself is pretty complicated, and the game overall is not really well optimized.When it boiled down to release I started to regret my purchase as despite the fact it's no longer Early Access, the game itself still feels largely incomplete. Buggy, no tutorial whatsoever, still not well optimized to run, and the ship building, although the interface is better, it still is really complicated a workflow overall. Not even the missions would work correctly. Which was a pain.Of course, having already purchased this game I decided to cling on and hope for the best, but then suddenly, the game went quiet on all mediums: forum, update schedule, and youtube.The entire dev team dropped out of the KV project, pretty much leaving only 2 behind. While it's more of a lack of interest than a 'take money and run' scheme (funds went to dev salaries), the 2 developers that DID stay behind, as much as I'd like to applaud them, can't do much either, not when they are also trying to work on a side project to make ends meet.I bought the game with high hopes that were never repaid. If you're here looking for a space sandbox, there are other, much better games that haven't been abandoned and left to rot in the pits of Steam. Don't buy this. It was never worth the $20, and never will be.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Backed this game more than a year and it was pretty much empty. I loved the concept and bought it. Came back a year later just to find out it's a disaster and the devs stopped working on it. Half the team chose to stop working on it and left the studio, and the two remaining devs need to eat so they work on a different side project. At least they are honest and told us why the game probably will never achieve the level promised years ago. At least they didn't run off with the money. It's about not having enough resources to go on.Two or three years ago I would have said what I was thinking back then : "The future of gaming will be brought through kickstarters and indie inspiration. Big companies don't care anymore". Today, the situation has changed. Bad devs ruined the system and the trust we had at the beginning. A majority of projects never achieve the features promised during the founding phase and run away with everyones money, leaving the game in a bad condition. This has to stop.Bottom line : amazing concept that never made it to release, despite the product being labeled as finished. I know this will not help the devs finish it, buy as it is today (v1.0.xx), it's not worth a buy :/

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												Kinetic void, watched the video read the forums in very early access (2013). Realised that it had massive potential bought the game. Played it, shelved it and like many others waited for a better game to come to pass.What Ive learnt since then, again like many others, I'll watch the video read the comments look at game play, read dev blogs and decide (usually correctly) that the game in question is just too over ambitious and throw my money at something else. Now the dev's are a smaller team this is one of the games that, personally, cant seen to be ever finished to the point where I could turn around and say "buy this".The game is difficult to get into, difficult to play because it still is and possibly awlays be an unifnished product. Dont treat this as a full release (it pushed out of early access for many reason im sure).Love building ships? (great looking too), Love flying em about with partially completed gameplay? Then buy it.looking for something that doesnt require a lot of reading up on tutorials, bug workarounds and shallow gameplay then sorry, just look somewhere else.What money I did spend on this game helped me save huge amounts of cash not spent on other early access games no matter how good the sales pitch is. So every cloud and all that...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												I loved this game, and at times I would just spend hours designing the perfect ship of my dreams, giving each module a story and a purpose.  I would launch out in to space and sail in its vastness engaging in combat with the surrounding AI.. and this is where the fun really ends. I first bought this game when it released into Early Access. It was my last 20 bucks, and I sat there clenching my virtual steam funds... finally giving in. Kinetic Void looked like a very good game, the updates were coming fast, people were hyped showing each other their creations and the lore behind them.  Even a member of the Yogscast posted a video depicting the gamer designing and testing out a ship in his created system.I played almost constantly, seeing what I could make next, and admiring other peoples' hard and dedicated work as well.  But then, suddenly the game is "released". I was quite shocked, I knew this couldn't be true... the game was a broken mess, did they finally refine the faction and trading system?  Is the combat more fluid and less buggy?  It seems they really haven't.  They left a note at the door. I was devastated, waiting two years in anticipation for all of these features.  I scanned the forums, witnessing developers deleting threads and banning customers asking sincere questions.  It saddens me, and I really thought this game was going to be a success, remembering the hype and positive feedback of the game in its Early Access release.  Hopefully other developers won't follow in their footsteps, but unfortunately it happens frequent enough.  Cheers.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Despite the negative reviews I decided it looked like the kind of game I would really enjoy... To be honest, I can't tell you if I enjoy the game or not, since I can't get past just how counter intuitive the ship building interface is. All I want to do is mirror a damn part. You have the tool, you click it, and as for mirroring? lets see, if by some miracle you do manage to get them to mirror.... they will be offset on the z axis, so they just wont align, and can you switch between the parts to do fine adjustment, nope, that button doesn't seem to do a damn thing. Either it's just not meant to do that, or whatever, but that's what I would think it would do... Dear devolopers, have you ever used any 3d modeling software? do you have any idea what 'mirror' means? I have spent the last hour since downloading it, trying to make a mirror image of a hull part. that's all I want to do. As it is, I'm going to just slap a bunch of parts together, throw some engines on it and call it good. I really hope that the actual game play isn't as counter intuitive as the ship building interface. Save your money folks, even on sale it isn't worth what I paid for it. Games are supposed to be fun, relaxing, enjoyable. Not vexing to the point of making any possible enjoyment moot.Update: After another 3 hours of messing with the ship designer, I figured out a few tricks to actually make the parts line up as a mirror image of eachother, but naturally, it is not how you'd think you'd be able to pull it off. Anyways made the ship, launched, got a mission message, and it was very vague.Managed to mine the required materials, and now I have no idea where to take them...Suggestion for the developer, go play Freelancer. Compare what you attempted to do with the 'freelance' mode of the game. get a mission, it tells you where to go, add a module, it shows what it does, how it affects everything.The KV interface is crap. It's a nice idea, but there's too much of the wrong information, and not enough of the right information. Buttons get hidden, the touch location changes, little bugs, that are obnoxious. It's nice that it's an open sandbox, and you get to choose where you get to go and when you go there, but what's the point if the game expects you to guess where you're suppoed to go to?Save your money, and your frustration.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												DO NOT BUY THIS TITLE!This game in unfinished, and currently development is being halted on this project.There are currently NO people working on this project who can finish it.The game has been taken off of early access prematurely, as there are still bugs and problems with the game.But according to the dev the games core features are done, BUT taking it off of early access makes it so people who block early access people will still see the title and might buy it.In the devs own words.http://imgur.com/yb8TKtW"I don't currently have a development team and the programming is beyond my skill range.""we are currently working on a side project in our spare time to hopefully generate more revenue"Keep in mind this game was a kickstarter project, AND a pay in early access title.Kickstarter goals and funds are supposed to be the amount needed to make this games a reality, but even with kickstarter funds AND steam release and money, this project has been halted.I do not believe the dev when he claims this game is finished and no longer needs to be in an early access state.I really do feel for these indie developers.It's something I aspired to myself at one time, so I can really feel for them when it comes to money problems like this.But the big issue right now is that this project has failed, sometimes projects fail, and you cannot expect people to cover your♥♥♥♥♥and throw money at you for something that has already failed once with the funds given.Do NOT support this game, there is absolutely no reason to because from what the dev says this game needs those funds to continue on being developed in the first place.Which means unless you have a few 100 friends willing to toss money into this hole, your money will just go to waste buying this game.This game already went down that path with kickstarter, it doesnt need another kickstarter, it needs to be removed from steam and closed down.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												It's a shame because this game has so much potential. The only thing good I have to say about this is that the ship creator is bloody brilliant. Real customisation to exactly where you want your weapons, cockpit, engines etc. If it's going cheap it's worth a go just to build a few ships and get really creative.   Outside the space station though. MEH. There isn't really anything to do. If you're lucky a mission might pop up, and you're even luckier if you're properly equipped to do it. Icons of asteroids litter the screen with no real method of filtering other than 'HUD off'. and the game lacks any real.. anything. So.. Mining the identical poo drop shaped asteroids over and over again for money gets boring very quickly, and for some reason they just explode when you've mined them. This tiny ship can blow up an item that is probably kilometers wide.. with.. mining lasers. NOPE.     Planets are empty and don't even have names.. There's no one really to talk to, at all. Would have been nice to hail other ships even if it was just for trading. The little cockpit man that pops up every time you fart or blink gets irritating, just text would have sufficed for the 60th Silicates you mined.     After nearly 3 years of development I'm severely disappointed. Yeah some aspects are good. But it's not playable and it's not a game. What a joke.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Here's a really good example of why Steam GreenLight usually doesn't work as planned. Originally I invested in this game for the idea, knowing full well it would be a while before development finished. However, the stunning slowness and absolute lack of proper patching didn't even remotely keep me interested to boot up the game. The few hours I messed around with it showed promise, especially in the ship building aspect. Unfortunately, this is real life -- developers get lazy, lose motivation, perhaps funding gets cut. This is exactly why Steam GreenLight was a failure. In retrospect, it's a good idea -- sometimes developers need help or the extra customer funding to push their game to the max. Keen Software is a good example of how to do it; they engage in their community very often, an update is out once every 1-2 weeks reflecting some sort of desire or functionality customers wanted, and it is well-recieved and fleshed out to be a game of its own. Badland Studio had promises, but fell short; a disappointment of a company at best.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												Normally I'm interested in getting in on a game before it's considered "finished," but it's been waaaay too long since there's been any substantive updates (or any updates at all for that matter). There are a lot of folks out there calling these guys "cheats" or some permutation of such, and I have to say I think that's unfair. I don't think they went into this planning to cheat anyone. Lots of folks dream about making great games, but there are so many things that have to come together to make that happen, and sometimes all it takes is one or two things falling apart. That said, I can't recommend something this unfinished, though it looked like the vision here was pretty grandiose, maybe too much so? If it's on sale for less than $5, you might buy it, build some ships, download some modded ships, and play around a bit, but don't go into it expecting Elder Scrolls in space or anything of that nature. I've been in the market for a good space sim and the best I've found is Starpoint Gemini 2, (and even that's not quiiiite what I was hoping for) so if you're reading this, you might go take a look at that instead. Is it a low blow or improper to recommend another game during a review? Maybe? If through some miracle this game ever gets finished, I will absolutely come back here and edit this review.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								As most reviews have said up to now, KV is in Early Access, and thus has a long way to go. That being said, the fact that it does have a ways to go is less of a reminder than something to look forward to(as is often the case in Early Access games) as this game is remarkably whole. You generate a universe, build a ship(or if that's not your thing there are plenty of perfectly fine pre-built ships), and launch it into space. You fly around vaporizing enemies(or getting vaporized...you'll learn your limitations very quickly) and completing missions, and, if your hull is about to crumble or you decide you can do better with the design, you return to the ship yard and make adjustments. As it stands, the missions do need work, as they are random and can become repetitive, and the help center and be opaque to people starting out, but for those looking for a space sim because of exactly what it is: a sim, this game is excellent.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												I bought this game in early access.  Suffice to say that steam did not allow refunds at the time.I found it hard to ever play this game, and now, seeing it in my library, I read the reviews to find that it might have gotten worse.If history is to look back at why steam's greenlighting system is broken, it must include this game/developer as an example.  That said, kudos to the game developer, because it is not easy to make games - certainly even this one.  However, this game is a perfect example of how an indie game can be overhyped (and overpriced), thus racheting up people's expectations.  On the back-drop of so many other space games (and even the re-release of some classics) I see no reason to recommend this game.  If anyone does like this game they owe it to the developer and all of steam to explain themselves.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								As of now, I cannot personally RECOMMEND that any consumer should buy this game for entertainment. Not in its current early access state. However! I can say that this game is currently moving on rails to success. After you read this review, please buy the game to show the developers some financial and informational support. Now to the actual game itself!Graphical aesthetics are great and match with the atmosphere. The soundtracks are perfect for inducing that soothing yet unsettling feel of colossal space. planets, and that vibrant, atmosphereic scifi feel.  Listen to it here. That is a reason that I was seduced into buying the game. As always, its the screenshots or cover of that book that you should not judge yet. As I segwayed further into the game, I was brought along a smooth road to introduction. The tutorial is a large ingame wiki, however I hope remake it into a more clever tutorial system. Well all hate tutorials that makes us feel like we are accomplishing nothing; I think virtually all of them are like that. It is hard not to do so. Skyrim did a good job with their tutorial. It was taught well as you were contributing to the story and felt a sense of accomplishment through it as you gt your first weapons, and always wanted to know who would live or die and what would happen next. I am getting off topic, perhaps I should give my adhd brain a break and finish the review later. . .

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								At an hour in the Shipyard I was struggling. At 2 hours in I was going crazy. At 3 hours in the Shi[yard it all came together. Using tutorials and the in game guide I finally feel I have a firm grasp on the ship building aspect and built a ship I am happy with. At 6 hours I have explored the sector portion of the game. Mining is a hassel and drones are still needing some work. But damn I love watching 500 attack drones swarm an enemy ship destroying it like bees defending the hive. I am still unsure of how to take over sectors and what my faction is actually called. At 10 hours I stopped caring for who is friend and who is foe. I live the Pirate path now destroying anything with an hp bar. Drones still do not return to my ship and they simply dissapear... very frustrating when I wish to do a Mass Warp Drive(MWD). Many abbriviations in the hanger are confusing and I have given up on trying to debriviate them. At 15 hours I still cant figure out most of the game play and there are these updates that I am not really seeing on my game. content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												Building my first ship was fun. It had a couple issues, namely that they gave you too many free parts instead of, say, a budget and a store, but it was fun to put a ship together from scratch(ish, it is modular after-all). But you hit launch with every anticipation and you get. . . ugh.X3 and Eve Online, pick solo or MMO and go play, because this? Not worth the time. To be perfectly honest, I warped to an asteroid, started mining, looked around empty space for a few minutes, realized how long mining was going to take, adn then? Then I realized the 'world' was far too empty to have anything to do with, to spend that kind of time waiting, especially without at least a chat-box to pass the time! Seriously, I cannot understand why games that cannot compete with such old predecessors keep getting released. The best game to come out since either of those was S.P.A.Z. . . which isn't exactly the same kind of game really, but it does the job. So, you could buy that instead as well. It isn't so much with the full-immersion 'you are your ship' exploration thing, but it is a solid game.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2013
Early Access Review
								UPDATE /// 8-22-14Game as far as construction of ships is far more functional than when I first got the game if not buggy and great strides have been made in this area to make it approachable. However once you get into the game itself the fundimental problems with the game shine through again.  Kinetic Void tries to reinvent the space sim wheel by making it square.  Controls are overly complicated for flight and space feels empty. Both of these problems have been solved by games made over a decade ago like Freelancer. Mouse flight needs to be implemented better. Warp gates need to be added to define sections of space. Weapons need to feel more powerful and stand out more. Procedural galaxies need to be dropped and replaced with a designed galaxy unless they can make them interesting which they currently are not. I could go on and on about how this game ignores problems that have been solved by older, better games.My suggestion... save your money. Early Access games either have good bones that need to be fleshed out or they're like Kinetic Void where all they have is a good idea but no idea how to impliment it into a good game.---------------------------------------This game is garbage it's barely even a game at the moment. I wish I could get my money back. :(

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, I came into the store one day, and while I was looking through the gaming archives for a new passtime, this popped up. I looked at the reviews, they didn't turn out too bad, so I took an immediate interest due to the pictures and effective wording done by the game developers of how it works, and also because of its' high praise by other players. So I bought, and downloaded it.After starting the game, a series of menus (the game played without much lag at all, it seems to be very effectively coded) that brought me to the ship creation menu. The whole thing was obviously still in development, as is the whole game, so I wasn't fazed. So far, it seems to have a solid menu system, and I love and hope that they try to make a little more sense of the icons, numbers, subsystems and such, because it wasn't all clear as to what they did, or meant, or how they affected the ship.So, after a few minutes of confused silence, I decided to choose one of the pre-made ships, and set off on my journey through space.I had fun. The distances were ridiculous, and the slip-space mechanic was a bit underdeveloped, but hey, it's a still-in-progress. What do you expect?Then I went into the fighting mode, in which I was destroyed in seconds, and had a good laugh at how horrible I was at simulators, and confused as to how exactly the weapons functioned. Once they did fire at the enemies, however, their power was surprisingly underwhelming.I see a lot of promise in this recently-aquired game, though I've barely tapped into its' evidently deep wells of entertainment. I do reccomend this game as it will continue to develop, and the onward march of progress is a brilliant thing to behold.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note that I barely have gameplay into the game. I originally got the game and spent hours building a ship, definitely going to be a simulation, you have to have housing for crew, where to eat, medic bay, cargo etc. If you build a ship wrong it will float im space with no acceleration or not be able to turn very much. When I first got the game it was an unlimited build, do whatever you want and it was pretty cool to build a monster ship to tear through space. However, last time I tried to play there was an update that gave you a credit limit so small you literally could not build a reasonably operable ship; Leaving out key parts such as the mess hall, medic bay and cargo etc. my updated ship still topped out at about 20 MPH and took literally about a minute and some to turn a 360 (buying only the cheapest parts necessary to fly and still ran out of credits). This has a lot of potential but hopefully that update was fixed. Or there was some feature option added I did not notice.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is in Early Alpha stage. So I took that in consideration and looked in the long run. Not just as to what it offers at the moment. Kinetic Void is a new genre of Spaceship Simulator. Having it's roots from the old freelancer and other games from the genre, it bring us new aspects of the game. Creating your own ship.Kinetic void let the players create their own ships, the way they want. You are able to design and create the ships you want for any purpose that may suite you. Want a nice looking sleek ship? Go ahead and make one. Want a big though ship like the Galactica? Go Ahead. And when we talk about creating ship, the Devs have gone further then just looks. All of the ship needs, from the power to radars, to crew quarters are your to choice to decide where they go. And to protect these important systems is one of your goal. Having, technically, no limits, you can build any ship you would have though about. But creating ships is not the only aspect. If this is something that is not your taste, you can simply take some of the default ship, or why not download some designs from the community workshop? Having over  thousands of community created ships, there is a ship for everyone out there... If designing is not your taste. Kinetic void launches you in a Procedural Generation world where Factions of NPCs each struggling to survive and conquer the galaxy in their own own. You are sent in this sandbox word with one goal: Living your life how  you want it. You want to be a merchant, selling Goods around the universe? Go ahead. Want to be a smuggler and go past blockades? Want to just shoot at things and be a pirate? Or defend the innocent? All is yours to decide. Kinetic Void aims to  be one of the, if not the space sim with the most opened up world, with the most customized game possible and it does it in a way that makes  you wonder: Why no one though of this before? If you are a fan of any space ship simulator, Kinetic Void is a must. From it's amazing artwork, to the infinity of customization, to the hard work of the Team, there's absolutely no reason not to have this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great space sandbox game. The only complaint is that the controls take some serious getting used to and understanding how to build a ship is a little difficult. However, there are some great videos on youtube, so if you watch just half of one of those you should get a good enough of a grasp to be able to figure out the rest. So once you have the controls down its just a matter of your imagination seeing how all of the ships are cutom built with various modules that can be stacked or layered so the possibilites are rather endless. Also it has a Workshop so its going to be Mod friendly, and you can already post up your ships and download your favorites. So not only do you get to build your own ship, paint your own ship, and arm your own ship, you can then go fly and fight in your own ship. I see great things for this title.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Anyone who's ever played early access games knows (or should) that this sort of thing is a possibility. Funding is a major problem with small developers, and many either don't plan well the proccess from start to finish ahead of time, things just don't go as expected, or they lose their minds and fall to stressors. Whatever the reason, we'll always end up with abandoned, or so called abandoned games. I've had it happen multiple times. I don't feel angry or regret it in the least. Because without the faith and support, we'd be missing some very nice games. You should wholly expect this when you see 'Early Access' and press that buy button.This particular game? If you're nosy about the awesome ship builder, and it goes on sale, sure, might be worth poking. Just don't expect a game. Else don't waste the money on what's essentially a set of legos that you can only share with screenshots. We can hope that the developers return to this game later with proper funding, but I wouldn't get my hopes up.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kinetic Void - Great ideas and concept, yet extremely unfinished and Work in Progress.At this point in time KV is very much an early alpha - if it is even that. Consider waiting on a more finished version, unless you are a big fan of custom ship building and have little interest in actually using the ship in question.Even the ship building itself is at this time incomplete. There is only one type of weaponry and many other critical features are still missing. The rate of update/patch progress is extremely slow.From my point of view as a gamer, avoid KV for now, but keep an eye on it. IF, and I stress the word IF, all of the promised features are actually going to get implemented some time in the future, this could turn out to be a very cool space sim. However given the current rate of updates and the state of the game, I expect KV to be a project that will never end with a high likelihood of never getting to the finish line at all.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kinetic Void is a stellar example of what many space related games should be.  Mind you while in early access many things are bound to change.  This game has a ship design system very akin to that used in Galactic Civilizations 2 which should be counted as a good thing.  The amount of customization that is offered to players in the design of their ships is a welcome sight as it’s something I have seen lacking in several games with the same feature.  From building the fastest fighter to the most looming dreadnought the experience of testing out different parts and experimenting with style is a great joy.Players are allowed to name their galaxy and select how many sectors and factions exist within, giving them some level of control of the environment that they start off with.  There is plenty of room for expansion in this area of the game’s development as further options in creating the play environment would add to the overall experience.The combat system is decent but could use some work.  While offering a manual mode of firing your ships weapons, there is a means of auto fire via the lock on, and pressing the assigned weapons group number.  In this early build I recommend avoiding the use of the auto fire as my weapons seemed resistant to firing let alone hitting.  However due warning, there does not appear to be any form of aim assist for now, and larger ships will have issues contending with smaller vessels you just cannot seem to hit.  (I am sure that these features will be ironed out in the future)Other than that there really isn’t that much left to do within the game, yet currently you can see the foundations for what have the potential to be engaging and immersive systems.  I full heartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys building ships from the ground up and actually being able to use them, as well as to anyone who enjoys space simulation games.  For what this game could be twenty dollars is a fair investment into seeing the developers get the chance to finish this game.  Yet to be fair it should be mentioned that in its current state Kinetic Void is arguably worth its asking price, while I love building ships and taking them for a spin there is just not enough to do currently.  With the occasional frame rate issue and bugs, for those on a budget or those who are not willing to drop twenty dollars on an incomplete game I would still recommend getting this game but when it is on sale.  This way you can still support the game, get a great ship builder, and access to what has the potential to be a great game.

								The game has a solid idea, but I can't recommend it. The ship building premise is cool, music is great, graphics look fine. But in the end, there just isn't a whole lot to do. number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not without merit, but thoroughly mediocre. The good:   The ship builder is the primary draw of this game- very versatile, can design whatever manner of ship you wish. The shipbuilder in Kinetic Void is more of a creative endeavour than anything else- unlike Kerbal Space Program, you do not need to worry about engineering constraints, efficiency, or performance very much. Perhaps that is appealing, perhaps not.The matter of taste:    Even in campaign mode, the game is very very sandboxy. You are given very little direction, just let out into the galaxy and accosted by radio about missions. Absolute freedom, but absolutely no story or direction.The ugly:   This game is utterly lacking in polish. Campaign mode opens up with an interminable tutorial, a series of pop-up text boxes listing what each button does- this is not a good way to present information. The interface looks awful, combat is unexciting. Space is ugly, a starless void with only waypoints as defining features. It is an exciting concept with utterly mediocre execution.TL:DR Buy this if you want to make model ships, or really like sandbox games

Up until now there has been nothing enjoyable about KV, my opinion oly, but with this patch the sim/game might finally be closer to a completely playable package than previously. Looking forward to what comes next and as such have rated the game a "tumbs up" at this point.EDIT (March 2015) - A concept with much promise in the beginning yet left to fail and die as a "game". The 'Build' element was tragic and problematic from the beginning, but all there was to the title. Now, even it has been nerfed. This is NOT a "game" but a broken concept. Beware!

content:

								The ship customization is certainly promising but at the stage of development I played it, I couldn't even figure out how to start a ship's engines without rifling through several videos on YouTube. number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												It is rare i write one of these, my time and words are not flung around lightly. This game is incredible fun even in its current state and i can only imagine what the future will hold. Currently it feels like a combination of Starmade and Eve. Starmade in how you build and manage your ships and Eve in how combat flows (But without insanely long buld times and skill trees ((yet???)) ). You can buid everything from tiny fighters to dreadnaughts the size of planets and beyond. Build you ship for looks or to focus your firepower tacticaly and as for guns....the new system gives you LOTS of options. The game has had it's bumps in the form of glitches but the creators actually listen to the community and talk with us to try to figure out whats going on so they can fix it. If i can hope for one thing to come it would be the ability to fly with friends.Update: The game now feels alive, so many ships flying about and reports coming in all the time keeping you up to date makes the game quite exciting now. All i can hope now flying about in space is that the developers really consider adding the ability of multiplayer. Flying about with friends or opening up a public server for massive clashes between player groups would be amazing. I can honestly see if this game gets multiplayer it becoming a cheaper and far easier alternative to EVE for people like me who refuse to pay monthly fees.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								(The rating is only for the current version its at itself) 8/10, This game is absolutely fantastic in my eyes, its got alot of bugs and parts wrong with it which is VERY understandable as its in Early Development, a few problems i ran into so far, some Game related the other ME related, firstly the mirroring system still needs abit of work, if you click and object to place and have not placed it just yet, you can turn the mirroring tool on and it works perfectly, but if you place (at the part where you can use the Arrows or loops to move/rotate) If you were to mirror once you've placed, it would go really weird, it wouldnt be mirrored at all, a problem that is most likely me related is, Every time i get in to this one galaxy that i've had created, I'm only in a corvette because after finishing up on that ship i came to realise you can make a BIGGER ship by clicking the number box above the construction menu *Derp* I keep getting swarmed upon spawn and as a noobie, even after figuring out the controls it gets abit hard to fight back which means i obviously either need a BIGGER ship, BETTER ship or just get better at the game haha xD but Oh my god, the Construction mechanics on this game, by far some of the best i've ever seen, i've been looking around for a damn long time for a game where you can have a HUGE Wide Free range of customization to your very own ship and the fact that I heard that hopefully this game would be getting multiplayer somewhile after the base game is complete, I was swooning, showing off your amazingly or Crazily made ships to your friends and facing off in battle just makes me drool! I have so much high hopes for this game and i've only managed to find out when it was on sale, i would of gladly payed the full price! (If and when i had the money xD) but this is a game for all Space Adventurers with a craving of customizing your very own ship to as much detail as the game can generate just for you, a Game i very much look forward to being completed by the development team! (as a wannabe Developer myself) I look up to you people, and i know almost everyone else does, so keep up the good work and to you people reading this, Take a chance, Buy this game and Hopefully you wont be disappointed!!!! Back up these Gorgeous Developers!!! <3

								this game is very cool and has lots of potential. when i first got it i played it for a little bit and then a few weeks later i got bored of it completely. there is so little stuff in this game to do once you build your♥♥♥♥♥♥.. it takes ages to get from point A to point B. the combat is ok..... if you can even get into a battle. there are so little enemies flying around and it takes forever to get to them or for them to come to you. and once you get to them they just fly off like your not there. i hope in the future they add more enemies or big fleets of ships for u to attack but thats it. its a good game if u just want to build a ship and float in space. for some reason, when ever i build a ship which takes about 30 mins and fly it in space the engines almost never work. and if they do the ship only goes 2miles per hour even when i make a fighter ship.this game has alot of potential but i cant recommend this until they make it a lot funner and add more stuff to it.

												UPDATE 11th of December 2014:So I gave it another try again. Hell how I regret it.Once the galaxy initialization process was at 100% the screen started to flicker.I waited. I waited longer. The game sent my Apple into limbo mode.I had to hard reset the machine. Hopefully I did not lose any data.BE CAUTIOUS!This is the lousiest piece of software I encountered for months, not to say years.I'm going to deinstall it. If there's a chance to wipe it off my library without erasing this review I'll do that, too. If I would be able to click two thumbs down, or even three, I would.Here's my initial comment from August:====For now this feels like pre-alpha software. Fiddling around with the editor is no fun for various reasons. (*)And the download took ages, too. If this would not be early access I'd now like to have my money back.(*)P.S.: I'm running the game in 1280x1024 on a low end Mac. There's an issue detecting clicks on at least all of the editor's top menu line icons: Even though you point at them your clicks don't get recognized properly, despite the icons getting highlighted. Instead there's only a small, let's say 4 pixel tall, detection area at lower icon end where clicks get recognized, even though the actual icons are much taller and clicking that low kinda feels like clicking off icon already.http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/11/35220315921355473/

content:

Early Access Review
								you spend a loving 2 hours perfecting your ship, giving it a vibrant color scheme to suit the style and how you play(will i be the red pirate with quad guns all down the sides? will i be the ho hum grey mining ship? oh, the choices i have) and set off into the vast abyss that is the last (dare i say, final) frontier. you will see stars and planets and be immersed in a galaxy that is teeming and alive. even at early access this game is fantastic and at the sale price of 12.99, you cannot go wrong. don't get it twisted, this game is not finished. you will be running out of things to do at the current moment, but for me, im happy to just drift through space dictating my logs. that is until some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ side swipes my ship and flies off. then i gotta fill out a space hit and run, and talk to the space cops, and they are always unhappy cause they just came back from a triple space homicide, and they just wanna go drink.... to make a long ramble short, buy this game, and enjoy.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Being a somewhat old school Eve/X3/spacejesus gamer, I was really interested in trying KV when I heard a few details in passing, Of course, I have the memory of a gnat, and forgot about it for a couple of weeks, I just bought and downloaded it now,.You start out with a deceptivly simple looking ship; cockpit, engines, guns and superstructure, however all these parts are modular, so you can move stuff around, have it at a different angle and so on, to personalise your ship as much as you like.I'm really happy to have got this now, as the developers have some great Ideas, and are planning to develop this game for a while after release, So, I can see myself puttering around in the galaxy for a long time to come.

								il be blunt. in its current state, this game is meh. only really the combat and the ship builing are near functional, although the ship buildign is pretty mutch done form what i understand. although i enjoy it very mutch, especialy scince the devs really interact with the community, (and i dont mean just through announcements, i mean they actualy comment on near everyones posts.) it is definitly not the best game in the world at this point.HOWEVER, the way the devs see this game in the future, in its completed state or near completed state, is amazing. from what i understand, is like the x series, with 2 big diffrences:1. completely procedural universes.this means that no two saves will be the same. evry time, you will start out with diffrent standigns among factions, in a diffrent star system, possibly under diffrent circumstances, etc. this will make the game, IMO, a completely diffrent expereince, especialy combined with the next and biggest thing on the list.2.BUILD YOUR OWN SHIPS!this is the complete awsoem part of this game. this is what sold it for me. you want to build a star destoyer to fly around in, go ahead! (watch out for lags though! (and the price to get that mutch material!)) enterprise? TIE fighter? BSG viper? a concept you jsut thought up of now? go ahead!in its current state, the shipyard is quite well flushed out. you can place most important modules and fill them with subsystems required for your ship to operate. you can even mount weaposn and use them! (WOHO! RAILGUNS!) unfortunatly, like any alpha game, it has its fair share of bugs, but those are fixed withign days of getting reported.jsut as a disclaimer, i am not a dev, nor am i in any sort of regular contact with them. as sutch, my above predictions are simply how i interpet announcements, state of the game, and other sutch publicly avalible plans. (an maybye a bit of what im hoping for it ;P)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												It's not that this game is going to fail... it's just that there is better. Functionality is this game's biggest issue, it throws a lot at you without you having a clue what to do, there are no tutorials and the controls are awkward. If they added xbox controller support it could work though.And yes there are much better games out there such as Starmade and Space Engineers. Kinetic Void is closer to Starmade but is kinda similar to the X series as well. It's great that they intended on melding the two together but it does need a lot of work and a lot more ideas to pull it off. Unlike Space Engineers, you can only design the exterior of your ship so you can't see inside. On the other hand there are enemy AI to fight.Ultimately this game just makes you want to stop playing immediately once you have built your ship. It serves as a good distraction for about 5 minutes (add another 10 for learning how the game works through trial and error). I really do hope that the developers can one day make this game into something brilliant but at this point there is no point in purchasing unless you really want to contribute to the success of this game.If you're looking for something similar to the X games but want more focus on customization, this game might interest you. Otherwise i'd say avoid this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												This is a very complicated game that needs a softer introduction for inexperienced players.Right now the "tutorial" presents a firehose of useful information without any experience using that information interleaved. That means it goes in one ear and out the other. Thus the "tutorial" system is extensive but is not actually suitable for true beginners. A better way to hook beginners would be to rapidly show them a quick-and-easy barely useful build without going into every detail of that build. Then get the player launched, guide them to another system/whatever and dock. Travelling to the other system should show some of the features/drawbacks of the build. Then enhance the craft. Launch. Script an easy Skirmish and guide them through it. Guide subsequent repairs. Return to dock. Buy replacements, upgrade, etc. That is a true tutorial -- what exists now is more akin to a one-time hovering tooltip.The graphics look good and the complexity revealed thus far hints at greatness. Unfortunately the time and rote memorization it takes to get initially acquainted with this game keeps me from truly playing it. I've never truly gotten out of the hangar before I had to quit and at that point there is nothing exciting about the game that makes me want to return to it any time soon. Hence I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								Basically a 3rd person space flight simulator, but with some very interesting twists. Most notabely the ability to design your own space ship, designs which NPC's are known to use as well, to keep the playing field balanced.Add to that relational status with numerous factions and reasonably large universe (can be set upon creating one) and you have yourself a great arena to test these designs in. Don't have an enemy? Create one by just randomly shooting ships that happen to pass by. You could always go mining or salvaging derelict craft for resources as well.Great graphics and awesome soundtrack, easy to learn controls, but sometimes not so clear on what, though optional, you mission objectives are make this a nice addition to any collection.There are some problems though, crashes, editor that has trouble doing certain things, but nothing really game breaking. And although I'm not much of a multiplayer gamer, I can see some real potential in that latest addition as well.Bare in mind though that this is still an project in development.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have very much enjoyed my experience in Kinetic Void thus far.  Currently, it reminds me of much of Digital Anvil/Microsoft Studio's Freelancer - a game I VERY much enjoyed for providing a rich, detailed universe.  Freelancer also had a wide range of systems and paths that a player could take, and allowed for customizable ships.Kinetic Void ups the ship design aspect allowing for a completely customizable ship.  Runner, gunner, fighter, freighter...  armed to the teeth or built for speed - or ANYTHING in between.  Build a galaxy to play in.There's a lot to see and do within the game, and I think having access to the design creativity of the Steam-going public as well as a talented design team will provide an excellent experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								I would recommend this game for most people, but not everyone. I have watched this game grow (and continue to do so) since July 2013 and am pleased by the progress that the developers have made so far, but there is still much work to be done in order to refine Kinetic Void. I would recommend this game to the following types of gamers:-Gamers who enjoy being creative in taking parts and building something of their own, but poses the patience to have to tweak, rework, or even recreate what they make after major patches come out. This game is still early access so it is understandable that these things happen and the patches generally make things easier.-People who enjoy a good RPG type simulation that takes place with ships, factions, and fleets, and can spend hours upon hours of trial and error to find out what works best in this game. -People who have ever played Battlestar Galactica Online: the game has a similar feeling to it and I feel that people who enjoyed that MMO would feel right at home with Kinetic Void outside of the ship creation menu-Peoplewho have played and enjoyed Kerbal Space Program: If you enjoyed the building mechanics in Kerbal, expect to enjoy Kinetic Void-People with a lot of patience in general who can wait for something to blossom to its true potential.I won’t lie, this game still has a lot of bugs (some are actually quite comical) but the Developers have done a good balance of both fixing these bugs as they come up and adding new content to the game, and I hope they continue to do so.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								I only have a couple of hours on this game so far, and those hours were purely from me painstakingly putting together my space ship.Having said that, I had an unbelievably good time doing so.  Even if the gameplay turns out to only be so-so, I'll still consider this money well spent.  The ship construction is incredibly good, both simple (though it takes some trial and error to figure out the eccentricities) and complex enough to satisfy... well... someone who has spent hours building a single ship.Something else that blew me away is the soundtrack!  I was nervous when the first track ended (mere minutes into my shipbuilding exploration!) that it would just repeat.  Nope!  Although tracks did repeat over my multi-hour session, there were enough and I enjoyed every single one so much that I was entertained the entire time.In sum, based on a couple of hours of gameplay; a fantastic ship builder and gorgeous soundtrack make me think this may join my list of all-time favorite games.
